9D29C5A7F7554D61AF360A2B749F9D0B.description: Students observe some things stay the same while other things change, and things may change slowly or rapidly.

3FEE50BEFBAC44E0BE54E006DB98A31B.description: Students use science and engineering practices, disciplinary core ideas, and an understanding of stability and change to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

426CF17CE0C946FEBC3029AE5EF8BEDE.description: Students observe the shape and stability of structures of natural and designed objects are related to their function(s).

33CD08B81E904A7581A22237CACD4AA3.description: Students use science and engineering practices, disciplinary core ideas, and an understanding of structure and function to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

71CEF4F165004775A8830E2730FA6031.description: Students observe objects may break into smaller pieces, be put together into larger pieces, or change shapes.

1F11DA353B0741B5AFF023E78A05F271.description: Students use science and engineering practices, disciplinary core ideas, and an understanding of energy and matter to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

B86EB4AE8B114994AF51C659D11DB85C.description: Students understand objects and organisms can be described in terms of their parts and that systems in the natural and designed world have parts that work together.

318B14BCEDF24C51B34D5F312ABA07E7.description: Students use science and engineering practices, disciplinary core ideas, and an understanding of systems and models to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

0C7AA399A8204DD0AC1B2772B4FAD61D.description: Students use relative scales (e.g., bigger and smaller; hotter and colder; faster and slower) to describe objects. They use standard units to measure length.

7D76A2D476CC4C3594A3602E33B2B16F.description: Students use science and engineering practices, disciplinary core ideas, and an understanding of scale, proportion and quantity to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

5CA088D3E88B4D8393500E4B717B5335.description: Students learn that events have causes that generate observable patterns. They design simple tests to gather evidence to support or refute their own ideas about causes.

3F565D5D5A474144A14E0C0746133934.description: Students use science and engineering practices, disciplinary core ideas, and cause and effect relationships to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

E834F94018384E4B914D67D550311CED.description: Students recognize that patterns in the natural and human designed world can be observed, used to describe phenomena, and used as evidence.

34A5F2637A024D2FA3FC79695FE9602E.description: Students use science and engineering practices, disciplinary core ideas, and patterns to make sense of phenomena and solve problem

05D0E787983D437894615329C3AF9CDC.description: Communicate information or design ideas and solutions with others in oral or written forms. Use models, drawings, writing, or numbers that provide detail about scientific ideas, practices, or design ideas.

79E4939B05F24A9B9778A5F56B912455.description: Obtain information using various texts, text features (e.g., headings, tables of contents, glossaries, electronic menus, icons), and other media that will be useful in answering scientific questions or supporting scientific claims.

4A8364937D8D4BD993C0AF3C00BE1C0B.description: Describe how specific images (e.g., a diagram showing how a machine works) support a scientific or engineering idea.

904E22465A08445583BE93421149C9FE.description: Read developmentally-appropriate texts or use media to obtain scientific and technical information. Use the information to determine patterns in or evidence about the natural and designed worlds.

BFF3440FF0864C28A5DD71A125D7AF5D.description: Students use observations and texts to communicate new information. This includes the following:

4000992B8F2A4DBBAA01BBF1595F6C2F.description: Make a claim about the effectiveness of an object, tool, or solution that is supported by relevant evidence.

EE3C887D9E7E417D87B55DE50B7C8692.description: Construct an argument with evidence to support a claim.

BD86537B10EA4ED8BD3C78E14F792F1A.description: Listen actively to arguments to indicate agreement or disagreement based on evidence, or to retell the main points of the argument.

A397C449FF8049099C382E5DA0B17252.description: Distinguish between opinions and evidence in one's own explanations.

58FA1C51E3164852881D85AD7B946CEF.description: Analyze why some evidence is relevant to a scientific question and some is not.

ACA5FF87AB4E494483131BCB2515D315.description: Distinguish between explanations that account for all gathered evidence and those that do not.

A8168303971E4E25A2917D7C0C5C1191.description: Identify arguments that are supported by evidence.

E2DD73FD0AD048C09278B4B14C298914.description: Students compare ideas and representations about the natural and designed world. This includes the following:

E3A66F90D2644012BB95BB29E62AD95D.description: Students engage in argument from evidence, in conjunction with using crosscutting concepts and disciplinary core ideas, to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

828CB05AF56D4F95ADB475F8586C86B2.description: Generate and compare multiple solutions to a problem.

C2259CF640454709BA8515C389CF8608.description: Use tools and materials to design and/or build a device that solves a specific problem or a solution to a specific problem.

F1E5CA2F4994456082C079783F20945F.description: Students use evidence and ideas in designing solutions. This includes the following:

5C50803BC3784F8E8373295824463B48.description: Use information from observations (firsthand and from media) to construct an evidence-based account for natural phenomena.

BC5A8040C81F49BD9A699AADF5CBD62D.description: Students use evidence and ideas in constructing evidence-based accounts of natural phenomena. This includes the following:

9AAA1F0BFA5249BD99BD0825ED7069B3.description: Students construct explanations and design solutions, in conjunction with using crosscutting concepts and disciplinary core ideas, to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

033BE1F4DDE9490CB44A502167A9D497.description: Use qualitative and/or quantitative data to compare two alternative solutions to a problem.

8B8964B9FFB144429BABE00C24AF5430.description: Describe, measure, or compare quantitative attributes of different objects and display the data using simple graphs.

ABA4860E766041D1A0FC27FEDF73D15F.description: Use counting and numbers to identify and describe patterns in the natural and designed worlds.

6AB3AF4420CE436C9056A592041D01EB.description: Students recognize that mathematics can be used to describe the natural and designed world. This includes the following:

E1ED8FF8903149C195E906D8BAC20DCA.description: Students use mathematics and computational thinking, in conjunction with using crosscutting concepts and disciplinary core ideas, to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

9D8857C48A2D47659C0F8D178227B443.description: Analyze data from tests of an object or tool to determine if the object or tool works as intended.

7ACBA93F24D04D60AEEAB765F4AF57B6.description: Compare predictions (based on prior experiences) to what occurred (observable events).

EC231E1D3FBF4BFFBFC15AB73FAD8139.description: Use observations (firsthand or from media) to describe patterns or relationships in the natural and designed worlds in order to answer scientific questions and solve problems.

AA16E338613046A38965F8316D79BB35.description: Use and share pictures, drawings, or writings of observations.

B4DB6CCB37C4424D906B4118DB24D9DE.description: Students collect, record, and share observations. This includes the following:

1EFD8981CF1F4B38A768DD9352BFCC4D.description: Students analyze and interpret data, in conjunction with using crosscutting concepts and disciplinary core ideas, to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

015F2B37588C40AABF2E148F294FEAEC.description: Make predictions based on prior experiences.

B0829C9515814FF7A8652860A59E7075.description: Make observations (firsthand or from media) and measurements of a proposed object or tool or solution to determine if it solves a problem or meets a goal.

DA676132C968444DBE7D4DB732FA8646.description: Make observations (firsthand or from media) and measurements to collect data that can be used to make comparisons.

4F359FDF5A8946DAA3BF0FC730C90CB2.description: Evaluate different ways of observing and measuring a phenomenon to determine which way can answer the question being studied.

C89F0536EE0D4B0EBFF04A48D799B877.description: Plan and conduct an investigation collaboratively to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence to answer a question.

7851AABFDFD0402EBB2D08D4053E4225.description: With guidance, plan and conduct an investigation in collaboration with peers (for K).

82614FC8FF104ECC8A6C2ABFAE2EA85B.description: Students plan and carry out simple investigations, based on fair tests, which provide data to support explanations or design solutions. This includes the following:

62998DAE92384DEE8F99FFB2043442B8.description: Students plan and carry out investigations, in conjunction with using crosscutting concepts and disciplinary core ideas, to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

BFE0B08350B9462C8F3FBDB6833419E6.description: Develop a simple model based on evidence to represent a proposed object or tool.

9C4859FA25554D8BB557EDB9D5001414.description: Develop or use models to represent amounts, relationships, relative scales (bigger, smaller), and patterns in the natural and designed world(s).

C1CA8BBA9379464F97C9D7F1E0330F1C.description: Compare models to identify common features and differences.

756E16A7A3624FAA980DD3DBCD5C2CFF.description: Distinguish between a model and the actual object, process, or events the model represents.

4E9BD7ABA32E41308EAD068AE217AB82.description: Students use and develop models (i.e., diagrams, drawings, physical replicas, dioramas, dramatizations, or storyboards) that represent concrete events or design solutions. This includes the following:

A8F9C7BC8D254557AF070694699BD829.description: Students develop and use models, in conjunction with using crosscutting concepts and disciplinary core ideas, to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

18B78191102B4F8CB6E7C6DF24E7A962.description: Students define simple problems that can be solved through the development of a new or improved object or tool.

B365CD096168420A8AFFDDC067110F1B.description: Ask or identify questions that can be answered by an investigation.

59AAC781EBF841FAAB7FAAE4D34E115D.description: Ask questions based on observations to find more information about the natural world.

973270811FC546EF8526339973C25294.description: Students ask simple descriptive questions that can be tested. This includes the following:

6846CF1A18DD447680AC38EE0BEFF707.description: Students ask questions and define problems, in conjunction with using crosscutting concepts and disciplinary core ideas, to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

45CA817A9A0F4EC2B96C7730C55888E5.description: An engineering problem can have many solutions. The strength of a solution depends on how well it solves the problem.

A2A15E2FAC0C4EA0967597DD57E3DC12.description: Scientific explanations are strengthened by being supported with evidence.

6752339560D247A8932A0DF4147D2A72.description: Science and engineers use many approaches to answer questions about the natural world and solve problems.

4705F424F75F43819CB94C906D5C204D.description: Science and Engineering Use Multiple Approaches to Create New Knowledge and Solve Problems

248D914494524C07A7821A7652D86593.description: Engineers solve problems to meet the needs of people and communities.

9375F02CDE764FECBD9C307A2A99F5E9.description: Science assumes natural events happen today as they happened in the past.

D25C0ED16C374618BF7CB846C291176D.description: Scientists use evidence to explain the natural world.

13F961A96E7B4672A47A3B07A516C86B.description: Science and Engineering Are Unique Ways of Thinking with Different Purposes

D7908002EE9A416CB7F0C35053DD470B.description: Creativity and imagination are important to science and engineering.

3D0B426203C14DEA8B269BCBEF3D30CD.description: People have practiced science and engineering for a long time.

4CEDB83C24A44AB98E04C95A5AE2B30D.description: People of diverse backgrounds can become scientists and engineers.

434DC63F79CF40A6A540DA9EFAF8D68B.description: Students use science and engineering practices, cross-cutting concepts, and an understanding of the nature of science and engineering to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

6F771E01843140B59742D15D74C1AE01.description: Taking natural materials to make things impacts the environment.

E4376C6DB76249C3A4E118BED2200B84.description: Every human-made product is designed by applying some knowledge of the natural world and is built by using natural materials.

B5A33614B1CD482B9D9B61E6FF3DCECC.description: Science and engineering involve the use of tools to observe and measure things.

757B314B1E5D4A1683CE294DBE2A4928.description: Interdependence of Science, Engineering, and Technology

45542F69A22C4855BBBEDFD8547CA809.description: Students use science and engineering practices, crosscutting concepts, and an understanding of the links among Engineering, Technology, Science, and Society to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

F311C0FC842E4E0FBED2B21BE369AC49.description: Because there is more than one possible solution to a problem, it is useful to compare and test designs.

7615D84918734C599C600EA4594AD94B.description: Designs can be conveyed through sketches, drawings, or physical models. These representations are useful in communicating ideas for a problem's solutions to other people.

3CBAFB04156E4A4D8EB1134D365A65FC.description: Before beginning to design a solution, it is important to clearly understand the problem.

53899541103542E88ABDE5AB55383A2F.description: Asking questions, making observations, and gathering information are helpful in thinking about problems.

CE790CCF371A43F3B40EBABD35A1D17F.description: A situation that people want to change or create can be approached as a problem to be solved through engineering.

4866C17C058444489D47B04ED89D0598.description: Students use science and engineering practices, cross-cutting concepts, and an understanding of engineering design to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

57E49571A8314F13A884FBE678BE1D77.description: Engineering, Technology, and the Application of Science (ETS)

602C7365039448EC915809CDC9B9BEF3.description: Things people do can affect the environment but they can make choices to reduce their impacts.

F1FCD8B0C579419FAB33842E7C92E67A.description: In a region, some kinds of severe weather are more likely than others. Forecasts allow communities to prepare for severe weather.

5822665B5F9C482D9A7D540EB5BDC75A.description: Living things need water, air, and resources from the land, and they live in places that have the things they need. Humans use natural resources for everything they do.

305D69263B3F4EB8A87B3BFC6250C98E.description: Students use science and engineering practices, crosscutting concepts, and an understanding of the Earth and human activity to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

9E225D5399B94BE098CACE21B9A30067.description: Plants and animals can change their local environment.

196714A31B6C45FAB518CFFD6C896B2B.description: Weather is the combination of sunlight, wind, snow or rain, and temperature in a particular region and time. People record weather patterns over time.

FAF19A5EBB8F47A1A5BA471FF4E531E9.description: Water is found in many types of places and in different forms on Earth.

90A2021B60B448ADA2B3FE90D8E5508D.description: The Roles of Water in Earth's Surface Processes

3063F7B6F2094D5D9E1D00858C9BAD09.description: Maps show where things are located. One can map the shapes and kinds of land and water in any area.

2A72A68DAEE0429C92C064D916765ABC.description: Plate Tectonics and Large-Scale System Interactions

726CF9FAD1504506A9C606090E1EC9C6.description: Wind and water change the shape of the land.

A397B52820254B63A11EDB0A0294388E.description: Students use science and engineering practices, crosscutting concepts, and an understanding of Earth's systems to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

86486BB88E18420085BDF9D722C86AA1.description: Some events on Earth occur very quickly; others can occur very slowly.

1A23082CF2E741F7B97118A5DC25EDE0.description: Seasonal patterns of sunrise and sunset can be observed, described, and predicted.

267E371B8ECB49DDBA567096E7B9074B.description: Patterns of movement of the sun, moon, and stars, as seen from Earth, can be observed, described, and predicted.

A74B69FADDA242D18BB84EDD5F03EF46.description: Students use science and engineering practices, cross-cutting concepts, and an understanding of Earth's place in the universe to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

EE6A719B4840462C8C2B0F7123AE9BD8.description: People use devices to send and receive information.

355E153278664098AF323B690FC71859.description: Objects can be seen only when light is available to illuminate them.

3ACC7669353B448193C8896E5CEDA751.description: Sound can make matter vibrate, and vibrating matter can make sound.

45736AAB6394408DB64A37DE9E8C6675.description: Students use science and engineering practices, cross-cutting concepts, and an understanding of waves and their applications in technologies for information transfer to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

F2DA68378CE248AF8919D789426D4449.description: Energy in Chemical Processes and Everyday Life

B70DF0A327294BDBBBF9AF2E22B5C694.description: Bigger pushes and pulls cause bigger changes in an object's motion or shape.

540FD0A1E46843CC862D556780C21DB5.description: Students use science and engineering practices, cross-cutting concepts, and an understanding of energy to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

B8B0554E935347B7A76EAD36866F1CF1.description: When objects touch or collide, they push on one another and can result in a change of motion.

B790C72873B145349E996E5F541B85EA.description: A bigger push or pull makes things speed up or slow down more quickly.

6E7A17FF526F4063A44AC5F77777CD24.description: Pushes and pulls can have different strengths and directions, and can change the speed or direction of an object's motion, or start or stop it.

33F447C909464E88927B448B0810B71D.description: Students use science and engineering practices, crosscutting concepts, and an understanding of forces, interactions, motion and stability to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

A15E6A1545A04821A3CA645C8A226EFE.description: Heating or cooling a substance may cause changes that can be observed. Sometimes these changes are reversible, and sometimes they are not.

10E2D621777E42C49F44721FEFB415A2.description: Matter exists as different substances that have different observable properties. Different properties are suited to different purposes. Objects can be built up from smaller parts.

E0C9EA9334064B2F85FF514B87770EF0.description: Students use science and engineering practices, crosscutting concepts, and an understanding of matter and its interactions to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

32555F7E1474487C83CF8BFF8494D1F4.description: There are many different kinds of living things in any area, and they exist in different places on land and in water.

628CE4C20398427EB091088CA2221DB7.description: Students use science and engineering practices, cross-cutting concepts, and an understanding of biological evolution to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

F510F457673541EFA5833D7B2D0A709D.description: Individuals of the same kind of plant or animal are recognizable as similar, but can also vary in many ways.

D49AD1537202457B96E3BBDF360D2AED.description: Young organisms are very much, but not exactly, like their parents, and also resemble other organisms of the same kind.

D8BA27FF6644496285030884C0FAD502.description: Students use science and engineering practices, crosscutting concepts, and an understanding of heredity to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

71EF64E335DD4EF4A0C1F8D745F9E72B.description: Plants depend on water and light to grow. Plants depend on animals for pollination or to move their seeds around.

3B6B15B39E714B29A36A91B5D5CC26DF.description: Students use science and engineering practices, crosscutting concepts, and an understanding of the interactions, energy, and dynamics within ecosystems to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.

6E083DE659A94A64A8A96A2D21C1A3AF.description: Animals sense and communicate information and respond to inputs with behaviors that help them grow and survive.

64C721B4C3D649DFB608795449416407.description: Animals obtain food they need from plants or other animals. Plants need water and light.

9BD874D290CA4810809B9BB57D7F66B7.description: Organization for Matter and Energy Flow in Organisms

A23B8F005F694133B1D9F331D370ACBC.description: Parents and offspring often engage in behaviors that help the offspring survive.

62203C5FFF5A4605AF64CF406C7B7041.description: All organisms have external parts that they use to perform daily functions.

DD297019A07F4B33B41A4458BC79B29D.description: Students use science and engineering practices, crosscutting concepts, and an understanding of structures and processes (on a scale from molecules to organisms) to make sense of phenomena and solve problems.
